notes.name: About "Editorial Calendar" project
notes.body:
This project shows how content is created and distributed by supreme Content Team at Exemplary Samples Co. 
It is divided into five stages:
1. Topic ideas are gathered in the first column. All tasks are created from the **NEW TOPIC** template, located to the far left. During the first phase, the ideas are being refined. After refinement, project manager (or editor) makes a writer's brief which they attach to each task.
2. Once a writer is assigned to the task, the topic goes in the second column. Once writers do research and complete writing, they attach the text file to the task and @mention the editor. 
3. The editor takes over the task, checks the text and makes sure that all additional files (like photos and visuals) are good to go. After proofreading, they @mention the SEO specialist so they can start the outreach.
4. The fourth column is meant for the posts that are ready but yet to be published.
5. Once the post goes live, it's moved to the fifth and final column.
Each task is divided into seven subtasks that are being completed as the process progresses. Also, labels are implemented for better transparency.

notes.name: Advice Needed
notes.body:
Leading creatives is not the same as managing them. To properly lead your creative team you have to be influential, but not intrusive. Leadership has to be apparent - management has to be done incognito.
1. **It is all in the eyes of the beholder** - All creative work is subjected to opinions that differ depending on an individual. From time to time you will receive a design, a text or sketch you are not fond of.  Don’t let your personal preference be the reason for its dismissal. Run it through the test to if performs well, and make results public. 

ihajnpaoiscja In his article published in Forbes magazine, [Victor Lipman](https://www.forbes.com/sites/victorlipman/2012/03/07/managing-creative-people-and-teams/#693a6325b108) recalled that nationwide focus group testing which proved that the insurance commercial he deemed “ridiculous,” was actually enjoyed by the public. It ran for years to come and became the most successful commercial ever, as well as foundation for further marketing activities.
2. **Meaningful praise over extra money** - Monetary reward can easily motivate employees that are performing mundane tasks they have no personal connection to. If they fold more boxes per hour than its anticipated, they should be rewarded accordingly - with bonuses. If morale ever drops, it can be uplifted once again with a small intensive.

asdas aascasdav asfafvasv. Creative employees, on the other hand, invest themselves in their work and create it through the reflection of their preferences. Even though they seem like though and independent individuals, the truth is that they are sensitive about their creations. Therefore, increasing bonus is not as nearly as effective as publicly (or privately - depends on preferences) praising them for a job well done.
3. **Creatives (usually) aren’t leaders** - They require guidance and thrive by having a “leadership pillar” to lean on to. However, by putting them in the position of power, one of two things can happen: 

- either they never establish authority and become stretched between newly found responsibility and maintaining a positive relationship with former team mates and friends; 

- or they go to the other extreme and become dictatorial oligarchs responsible for tension and stress within the team.

Profile of a good leader and a profile of a creative person are very different. According to [research](http://journals2.scholarsportal.info/details.xqy?uri=/01918869/v54i0003/420_gigatrbeasp.xml), the best creatives exhibit many characteristics that prevent them from being effective leaders: they are rebellious, antisocial, self-centered, and the only time they will stick their neck out is if the comrade is in distress.

Disclaimer: There are rare cases when your top creative can become a leader and take on a managerial position. However, in those cases, you must ask yourself: “Do I want my top creative man to waste his time on organizational issues, or should I allow him to focus on what he does best?”
